webTitle: Ramping up GST while cutting company tax will be a tough sell for Hockey

fields.bodyText: Every taxation review really boils down to two questions: how much should we tax? and how should we raise that tax? The tax paper released by Joe Hockey on Monday is clearly focused on increasing tax through sales rather than from income. It will be a tough sell and Hockey has suggested the paper is the start of a conversation. If Hockey is to produce any changes to the current system, he will need to be prepared to talk and listen for a very long time. As John Quiggin pointed out yesterday, there aren’t many new ideas in the discussion paper. In 2010 we had the Henry tax review, and pretty much a lot of what is covered in the discussion paper was given a once over back then. The current review is more focused on the GST than in the Henry Review (the Labor government was too scared to even examine the issue), but it also has a few blind spots. For example, the Henry tax review contained a whole section on “taxes to improve the environment”, whereas this current review ignores it and boasts instead that “last year the government abolished the carbon and mining taxes, which were a drag on growth”. Removing the carbon tax also lost around $9bn in tax revenue over the next three years, but oddly that doesn’t get a mention. Overall the paper is framed as trying to “deliver taxes that are lower, simpler, fairer”. But that’s just what they tell the tourists. The paper really is about raising more tax. It hints at this when it compares our tax system to other nations and makes the point that “Australia has a relatively low tax burden compared to other developed countries.” It’s hard to start from there and then suggest there needs to be less tax raised. How the tax is raised is very much directed towards individuals rather than companies, suggesting that more should be paid through their spending rather than through their income. The paper makes a great deal of the fact Australia relies less on consumption taxes (like the GST) than other nations in the OECD: It also notes that our GST rate is much lower than most others: As a result, we are more reliant upon income taxes from individuals or companies. This is viewed as a negative because broad-based consumption taxes are generally more stable than income taxes – especially during recessions. For example, from 2007-08 to 2009-10 Australian individual income tax revenue fell 3.1% and company tax revenue fell 15.4% – but GST revenue rose 3.6%. It’s worth noting however that being reliant on consumption taxes is no cure-all. Of the 33 OECD nations with broad-based consumption taxes, 21 have lifted them since the start of the GFC. But a look at Australia’s tax mix since 1978 shows we have certainly become more reliant upon company tax revenue: In 1978-79 company tax revenue accounted for just 13.2% of all federal government tax revenue. By 1999-2000 – just before the mining boom took off – it had only risen to 16.2%. But in 2007-08, at the peak of the boom, it was up to 22%. Even now, despite the end of the investment phase of the mining boom, it still accounts for around 20% of all tax. The paper notes that in the OECD only Norway is more reliant upon company tax than Australia. The concern from the government about company tax is that not only is it subject to some wild swings, it might also be in danger of being lost through tax evasion – because our 30% company tax rate is among the highest in the OECD: In contrast with the global increases in spending taxes, 21 nations in the OECD have lowered their company tax rate since the GFC. The paper noted that 58% of our company tax revenue is paid by just 960 companies (out of around 800,000). This means that the revenue is very much at risk from companies that might indulge in “tax planning” – which is the paper’s very diplomatic way of saying “tax avoidance”. It’s an irregular verb: you “tax plan”; I “tax minimise”; he is going to jail for “tax evasion”. And if you think that means it’s a race to the bottom, then you’re right. The response from the government about concerns that companies might avoid tax by notionally setting up shop in a low tax country – such as Ireland with its 12.5% rate – is to suggest we lower our tax rate. The paper argues that a lower company tax will “reduce the incentive for tax planning and profit shifting from Australia.” This suggestion is a pretty weak response to concerns about international tax shifting and avoidance that Joe Hockey was so gung-ho about reducing at the G20 last year. It’s pretty dispiriting, and it requires a lot of faith that these lower taxes will lead to greater investment, which will in turn lead to more jobs, higher incomes and better standard of living. Of course it won’t raise the revenue base. However devoted you are to supply-side economics, the reality is that when you cut the company tax rate, company tax revenue falls. The paper notes studies in the UK that suggest increased investment from a lower company tax rate could reduce the revenue loss by between “45 and 60 per cent” – but that still leaves less total revenue. And the paper emphasises that it doesn’t want to raise that extra revenue from individual income tax. It notes that bracket creep – wherein increases in your income through wage rises takes you into a higher tax bracket – “can reduce participation incentives for some groups”. It worth though having a bit of calm about bracket creep. Yes, if you go from earning $75,000 to $82,000 you do go from a marginal tax rate of 32.5% to 37%, but remember it is only for the additional amount earned over $80,000. Also, while there has been some bracket creep due to the lack of any tax cut since 2008-09 – when the second tier tax threshold was raised from $75,000 to $80,000 – the current level of second tier income tax is 1.37 times the average income of $58,700 that is still only just below the 30 years average of 1.42: The top tax threshold of $180,000 remains more than three times the average annual earnings of around $58,700 – well above the 30 year average of the top tax bracket being just 2.26 times average earnings. In 2002-03 the top tax bracket was just $60,000 – or around 1.63 times average income. Were that ratio in place now, the top tax rate of 47% (including the debt levy) would kick in at a much lower income around $95,600. And it is worth noting that because the marginal tax rates have been cut and the tax-free thresholds have been raised, we all pay much less tax than we used to. In 1984-85, for example, someone on the average wage paid around 20.5% of their income in tax whereas now they pay just 17.8%. And thirty years ago, someone on twice the average earnings would have been paying 32.6% of their income in tax; now they pay only around 26.7%. While we are more dependent upon income taxes for government revenue than other nations, our actual income tax rate is not very high. The income tax wedge which measures both tax paid and also the benefits received as a percentage of income earned places Australia well down the list of other OECD nations: So where will the revenue come from? While the paper does talk of broadening the GST, the more likely option is to just raise it. Most consumption taxes around the world have exemptions for things like food and education – the UK for example has many such exemptions. But this, of course, is regressive and disproportionally impacts poorer households. So would require some income tax cuts to offset it – not something you want to do when you’re actually trying to increase the amount of tax you are raising. The paper also notes the massive growth in property losses and the use by high income earners of negative gearing – and importantly the 50% discount on capital gains tax – to reduce taxation. But alas, Joe Hockey seems destined to not change it. I have previously debunked Hockey’s bizarre view on the benefits of negative gearing. Fortunately, the massive tax concessions to superannuation (that I have discussed previously) also feature highly in the discussion paper. Given the treasury estimates the revenue forgone is around $27bn a year, it’s little wonder they are under the gun. And even more fortunately, there does appear to be room for bipartisan agreement on this. Another suggestion in the paper is to pay for cuts to company tax by removing dividend imputation. Dividend imputation gives tax free dividends to Australian shareholders. It’s a big bonus for investors. Given “mum and dad” investors and self funded retirees are among those who enjoy that benefits, a policy to remove it would be politically courageous. But that is the case with all tax changes. Yes this tax paper may not have much new, and does repeat the Henry tax review in many ways, but it is still a debate worth having. If we do want the government to provide a certain level of services – whether for health, education, or social security – then we do need to look at how it should be funded. Let the conversation begin!
